doc.field: Sofia Sequenzia Papers on Hugo Gellert
Sofia Sequenzia Papers on Hugo Gellert

This collection contains three audio cassette tapes of a 1981 interview by Sofia Sequenzia with muralist and illustrator Hugo Gellert. Sequenzia conducted a three-hour interview with Gellert for a freelance article she published in the National Guardian. The audio recordings of the interview appear to be incomplete and are on 3 tapes numbered 1, 4, and 6. The interview is accompanied by Sequenzia's notes and a handwritten transcript. The collection also includes flyers, programs, and articles from events dedicated to Gellert's life and works.

Sequenzia conducted a three-hour interview with Gellert for a freelance article she published in the National Guardian. The audio recordings of the interview appear to be incomplete and are on 3 tapes numbered 1, 4, and 6. The interview is accompanied by Sequenzia's notes and a handwritten transcript. The collection also includes flyers, programs, and articles from events dedicated to Gellert's life and works.

This collection contains three audio cassette tapes of a 1981 interview with artist Hugo Gellert conducted by Sofia Sequenzia. The audio recordings of the interview are on 3 tapes numbered 1, 4, and 6. The interview is accompanied by Sequenzia's notes and a handwritten transcript. The collection also includes flyers, programs, and articles from events dedicated to Gellert's life and works.
Sophia Sequenzia conducted a three-hour interview with muralist and illustrator Hugo Gellert in 1981, which she used for a freelance article published in the National Guardian.

Hugo Gellert was a communist graphic artist whose work appeared in a number of radical publications including the Masses, the Liberator, and the New Masses. His is most well-known for his depictions of working-class struggle and artwork supporting organized labor.
Donated by Sofia Sequenzia in 2016. The accession number associated with this gift is 2017.009.

Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact tamiment.wagner@nyu.edu with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.
